{{pp-move-indef}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox officeholder |name = Eliot Spitzer |image = Eliot Spitzer.jpg |order = 54th [[Governor of New York]] |lieutenant = David Paterson |term_start = January 1, 2007 |term_end = March 17, 2008 |predecessor = [[George Pataki]] |successor = [[David Paterson]] |office1 = 63rd [[Attorney General of New York]] |governor1 = George Pataki |term_start1 = January 1, 1999 |term_end1 = December 31, 2006 |predecessor1 = [[Dennis Vacco]] |successor1 = [[Andrew Cuomo]] |birth_name = Eliot Laurence Spitzer |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1959|6|10}} |birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = [[Silda Wall Spitzer|Silda Wall]] (1987–2013) |children = 3 |education = [[Princeton University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Harvard University]] ([[Juris Doctor|JD]]) |signature = Eliot Spitzer Signature.svg }} '''Eliot Laurence Spitzer''' (born June 10, 1959) is a retired American politician, attorney, and educator. A member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], he served as the 54th [[Governor of New York]] from 2007 until 2008. Spitzer worked as an attorney in private practice with several New York law firms before becoming attorney general, where he worked for six years as a prosecutor with the office of the Manhattan district attorney. He was then elected to two four-year terms as the [[New York State Attorney General|Attorney General of New York]], serving from 1999 to 2006. He was elected Governor of New York and served as the [[List of Governors of New York|54th Governor of New York]], from January 1, 2007, until his resignation on March 17, 2008, in the midst of [[Eliot Spitzer prostitution scandal|a prostitution scandal]].{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2008/POLITICS/03/12/spitzer/index.html |title=Spitzer to step down by Monday |accessdate=March 12, 2008 |publisher=CNN | date=March 12, 2008}}[https://www.npr.org] | March 12, 2008 | Spitzer Resigns After Sex Scandal, Pressure | [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=88134976] Since his resignation, he has worked as a television host and an adjunct instructor; Spitzer also ran for [[New York City Comptroller]] in [[New York City comptroller election, 2013|2013]] and made private investments in a start-up company.{{cite news|last1=Ember|first1=Sydney|title=Spitzer Returns, Taking Aim Again at Financial Analysts|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2014/07/22/spitzer-returns-taking-aim-again-at-financial-analysts/|accessdate=29 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=22 July 2014}} ==Early life and education== Spitzer was born in the [[The Bronx, New York|Bronx]], the son of Anne (née Goldhaber), an [[English literature]] professor, and [[Bernard Spitzer]], a real estate mogul.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/12/nyregion/12spitzer.html|title=Gilded Path to Political Stardom, With Detours | work=The New York Times | first=Danny | last=Hakim | date=October 12, 2006 | accessdate=May 1, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wargs.com/political/spitzer.html|title=The Ancestors of Eliot Spitzer}} His paternal grandparents were [[History of the Jews in Galicia (Eastern Europe)|Galician Jews]], born in [[Tovste (urban-type settlement)|Tluste, Poland]], now [[Ukraine]]. His maternal grandparents, born in the 1890s, were [[Jewish]] emigrants from Ottoman-era Palestine (now [[Israel]]).[http://www.jewishjournal.com/books/item/eliot_spitzer_examined_20100513 Eliot Spitzer, Examined], Jewish Journal, Steve Weinberg, May 13, 2010{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/12/nyregion/12spitzer.html|title=Gilded Path to Political Stardom, With Detours | work=The New York Times | first=Danny | last=Hakim | date=October 12, 2006}}Lowenstein, Roger. [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/16/business/yourmoney/16shelf.html "As Governor, What Would His Battles Be?"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 16, 2006. Retrieved April 13, 2008. "Eliot and his two siblings grew up in the prosperous Riverdale enclave of the Bronx, fed on progressive politics and duly enrolled in private schools."{{cite news | first=Martin | last=Jaffee |title=Small college awakened future senator to service | date=April 4, 2008 | url=http://www.jtnews.net/index.php?/columnists/item/4197/C6 | work=JTNews | accessdate=April 16, 2009}}{{citation|last=Masters|first=Brooke A.|title=Spoiling for a Fight: The Rise of Eliot Spitzer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EwkydsNQJMsC|page=21|publisher=Macmillan|year=2007}} "Eliot's maternal grandfather, Joseph Goldhaber...[a] teacher who had emigrated from Israel..." Spitzer is the youngest of three children. He was raised in the affluent [[Riverdale, Bronx|Riverdale]] section of [[The Bronx]] in New York City. His family was not religious, and Spitzer did not have a [[Bar Mitzvah]].{{cite news|last=Hakim|first=Danny|title=Gilded Path to Political Stardom, With Detours |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/12/nyregion/12spitzer.html?pagewanted=all|work=The New York Times|date=October 12, 2006|accessdate=March 24, 2011}} He is a 1977 graduate of [[Horace Mann School]]. After scoring 1590 out of 1600 on the [[Scholastic Aptitude Test]] (SAT), he received a Bachelor's degree at [[Princeton University]] and his [[Juris Doctor]] at [[Harvard Law School]]. At Princeton, he was elected chairman of the undergraduate student government and graduated in 1981. He has said he received a perfect score on the [[Law School Admission Test]] (LSAT),Healy, Patrick.[http://travel2.nytimes.com/2006/10/18/nyregion/18faso.html?pagewanted=all "An Ill-Timed Candidate Believes His Time Is Now"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 18, 2006. Retrieved January 1, 2007. and went on to attend [[Harvard Law School]], where he met and married [[Silda Wall Spitzer|Silda Wall]]. Spitzer was an editor of the ''[[Harvard Law Review]]''. ==Legal career== Upon receiving his [[Juris Doctor]], Spitzer clerked for Judge [[Robert W. Sweet]] of the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, then joined the law firm of [[Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison]]. He stayed there for less than two years before leaving to join the New York County District Attorney's office. Spitzer joined the staff of Manhattan District Attorney [[Robert M. Morgenthau]], where he became chief of the labor-racketeering unit and spent six years (1986-1992) pursuing [[organized crime]].{{cite web|last1=Donway|first1=Roger|title=Eliot Spitzer: Ayatollah General|url=http://atlassociety.org/commentary/capitalism-and-morality/capitalism-morality-blog/3650-eliot-spitzer-ayatollah-general|website=The Atlas Society|accessdate=7 October 2016}} Spitzer's biggest case came in 1992, when he led the investigation that ended the [[Gambino crime family]]'s organized crime control of Manhattan's trucking and garment industries. Spitzer devised a plan to set up his own sweatshop in the city's garment district, where he turned out shirts, pants and sweaters, and hired 30 laborers. The shop manager eventually got close to the Gambinos, and officials were able to plant a bug in their office. The Gambinos, rather than being charged with extortion – which was hard to prove – were charged with antitrust violations. Joseph and [[Thomas Gambino]], the latter being an extremely high-ranking member, and two other defendants took the deal and avoided jail by pleading guilty, paying $12 million in fines and agreeing to stay out of the business.{{cite news | first=Adi| last=Ignatius| title=Wall Street's Top Cop| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1003960,00.html| work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]| date=December 30, 2002| accessdate=November 4, 2006}} Spitzer left the District Attorney's office in 1992 to work at the law firm of [[Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom]].{{Cite news| url =http://www.biography.com/people/eliot-spitzer-279076#background |title=Eliot Spitzer Biography|publisher=[[FYI (U.S. TV channel)|Bio.]] |accessdate= September 23, 2014}} From 1994 to 1998 he worked at the law firm Constantine and Partners on a number of consumer rights and antitrust cases. ==New York State Attorney General== ===Campaigns=== {{Main|New York Attorney General elections}} {{See also|Electoral history of Eliot Spitzer}} ====1994 campaign==== In February 1991 [[Robert Abrams]], a Democrat and the longstanding New York State Attorney General, announced his intention to run for the U.S. Senate seat for New York then occupied by incumbent Republican U.S. Senator [[Al D'Amato]].{{cite news|last1=Verhovek|first1=Sam Howe|title=Abrams to Run For U.S. Senate In 1992 Contest|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/02/02/nyregion/abrams-to-run-for-us-senate-in-1992-contest.html|accessdate=7 October 2016|publisher=The New York Times|date=2 February 1991}} When he announced his intention the Senate election was almost two years in the future. Abrams won the nomination in the Democratic primary but narrowly lost to D'Amato in the general election in November 1992. Ten months later, in September, 1993, Abrams announced that he would resign his position as Attorney General as of December 31, 1993, although he still had one year remaining in his term. To fill this vacancy the New York State Legislature elected Assemblyman [[G. Oliver Koppell]] to serve out the remainder of the Attorney General's term during 1993. Thirty-four-year-old Spitzer decided to run as a Democratic candidate in the 1994 election for Attorney General, as did Koppell, Brooklyn Family Court Judge [[Karen Burstein]], and Kings County DA [[Charles J. Hynes]]. At the time, Spitzer was a young and relatively unknown defense attorney representing white-collar criminals. When he announced his campaign Spitzer suggested that, if elected, he would use the state's antitrust laws to pursue corporate polluters.[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BN&p_theme=bn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF97CFAD23DF11&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM News Archives: The Buffalo News]. Nl.newsbank.com (May 5, 1994). Spitzer was the only candidate to support the [[Capital punishment in New York|death penalty]]. In a televised debate among the candidates, Spitzer was criticized for financing his campaign using $3 million of his own and family money.{{cite news|title=Attorney General Race Wide Open|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zxQxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=leAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4158,3131582&dq=elliot+spitzer&hl=en|accessdate=30 September 2016|work=The Daily Gazette (Schenectady)|agency=Associated Press|date=12 September 1994}} Despite heavy funding from his own family, he placed last among the four Democratic candidates for the nomination, receiving just 19% of the vote. Burstein, the only woman and gay candidate,{{cite news|last1=Mokrzycki|first1=Mike|title=Burstein just ahead of Koppell|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0RQxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=leAFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3130,3514464&dq=elliot+spitzer&hl=en|accessdate=30 September 2016|work=The Daily Gazette|agency=Associated Press|date=14 September 1994}} won the primary with 31% of vote.[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=88209 NY Attorney General – D Primary Race – Sep 13, 1994]. Our Campaigns. Burstein subsequently lost in the general election to Republican [[Dennis Vacco]], part of a nationwide Republican sweep, that included the election of Republican [[George Pataki]] as the new Governor of New York displacing the Democratic incumbent, Governor [[Mario Cuomo]]. ====1998 campaign==== Four years later, Spitzer again wanted to run for Attorney General and on May 6, 1998 he announced he would run for the office for a second time.[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BN&p_theme=bn&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF9ADDE8887B16&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM News Archives: The Buffalo News]. Nl.newsbank.com (May 6, 1998). On May 28, he emerged as the front-runner among the Democratic candidates, ranking first at the Democratic convention with 36% of the vote. He also had the most amount of money, with over $2 million.[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/28/nyregion/primary-ahead-in-attorney-general-race.html Primary Ahead in Attorney General Race – New York Times]. ''The New York Times''. (May 28, 1998). In September, he won the Democratic [[primary election]] with 42% of the vote. He defeated State Senator [[Catherine Abate]] (27%), Koppell (22%), and former Governor's Counsel Evan Davis (9%).[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=122181 NY Attorney General – D Primary Race – Sep 15, 1998]. Our Campaigns. In the general election Spitzer would face the incumbent, Dennis Vacco, a Republican. In late October, he conceded that his father lent him most of the money he raised. He financed both campaigns from two sets of loans: $4.3 million in 1994 and $4.8 million in 1998, both from [[J.P. Morgan & Company]]. Spitzer stated "I have worked long, long hours for my dad and for various businesses. Look, I'm not saying that I am underpaid. But any effort to challenge the propriety of that fee is way off base."[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/28/nyregion/1998-campaign-money-spitzer-concedes-that-his-father-has-helped-pay-for.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: THE MONEY; Spitzer Concedes That His Father Has Helped to Pay for Campaigns – New York Times]. ''The New York Times''. (October 28, 1998). On October 28, ''[[The New York Times]]'' endorsed Spitzer saying both candidates were flawed but "Vacco's performance and his key policy positions make him an even worse choice. In only four years Mr. Vacco has turned an important office with a distinguished public-service tradition into a patronage mill known for taking suspect contributions and for his mixed record on such key issues as women's right to abortion." They also said "Spitzer has promised a politically moderate approach that puts the public interest ahead of rigid philosophy and special-interest contributors."[https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/29/opinion/eliot-spitzer-for-attorney-general.html Eliot Spitzer for Attorney General – New York Times]. ''The New York Times''. (October 29, 1998). In November, Spitzer went on to defeat Republican incumbent Dennis Vacco by a small margin of victory of 0.6%. Spitzer did not win a single county in [[Upstate New York]]. Amazingly, he won just 6 counties in the state: [[New York County, New York|New York]] (81%), [[Bronx County, New York|Bronx]] (80%), [[Kings County, New York|Kings]] (75%), [[Queens County, New York|Queens]] (67%), [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester]] (52%), and [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland]] (48%).[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=79411 NY Attorney General Race – Nov 03, 1998]. Our Campaigns. ====2002 reelection campaign==== In 2002 Spitzer ran for re-election and a second term as New York's Attorney General. Spitzer defeated Republican Judge [[Dora Irizarry]] 66%–30%.[http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=1657 NY Attorney General Race – Nov 05, 2002]. Our Campaigns. ===Tenure overview=== As Attorney General, Spitzer stepped up the profile of the office. Traditionally, state attorneys general have pursued [[consumer rights]] cases, concentrating on local fraud while deferring national issues to the [[Federal government of the United States|federal government]]. Breaking with this traditional deference, Spitzer took up civil actions and criminal prosecutions relating to corporate [[white-collar crime]], securities fraud, Internet fraud, and environmental protection.{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Gross|authorlink=Daniel Gross|title=Eliot Spitzer – How New York's attorney general became the most powerful man on Wall Street |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2108509/sidebar/2108525 |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |date=October 21, 2004 |accessdate=March 14, 2008}} The New York Attorney General's office has [[Wall Street]] (and thus many leading corporate and financial institutions) within its jurisdiction. Also, the New York Attorney General wields greater than usual powers of investigation and prosecution of corporations under New York State's General Business Law. In particular, under the [[Martin Act]] of 1921, the New York Attorney General has the power to [[subpoena]] witnesses and company documents pertaining to investigations of fraud or illegal activity by a corporation. Spitzer used this [[statute]] to allow his office to prosecute cases which have been described as within federal jurisdiction.{{cite news |first=Steve |last=Kroft |title=The Sheriff of Wall Street |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2003/05/23/60minutes/main555310.shtml |publisher=[[CBS News]] |date=May 25, 2003 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}}{{cite news |first=Raymond J. |last=Keating |title=Spitzer's 'federalist papers' are onerous |url=http://blog.nysrpa.org/?p=513 |work=[[Newsday]] |date=August 21, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}} Spitzer used this authority in his civil actions against corporations and criminal prosecutions against their officers. It proved useful in the wake of several U.S. [[corporate scandal]]s that began with the collapse of [[Enron]] in 2001. Several of these corporations, as well as the brokerage houses that sold their stock, were accused of having inflated stock values by unethical means throughout the 1990s. When inquiries into these allegations by the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) and [[United States Congress|Congress]] failed, Spitzer's office used its subpoena power to obtain corporate documents, building cases against the firms both in courtrooms and in [[public opinion]]. During his term in office Spitzer also commissioned a 1999 study of the [[NYPD]]'s [[stop-and-frisk]] practices.{{cite web|url=http://www.dianepublishing.net/ProductDetails.asp?ProductCode=0788187538|title= New York City Police Department's 'Stop & Frisk' Practices: A Report to the People of the State of New York from the Office of the Attorney General|publisher=Diane Publishing}} In 2004, ''[[The Nation]]'' endorsed Spitzer as a possible Democratic candidate for vice president, stating that he was "the single most effective battler against [[corporate abuses]] in either political party".[http://www.thenation.com/blogs/thebeat?bid=1&pid=1295 Running for Running Mate]. ''The Nation''. Retrieved March 16, 2010. He was, however, not chosen. In January 2005, the president of the [[U.S. Chamber of Commerce]] described Spitzer's approach as "the most egregious and unacceptable form of intimidation we've seen in this country in modern times".{{cite news |title=U.S. group is taking on Spitzer |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/01/06/business/worldbusiness/us-group-is-taking-on-spitzer.html |publisher=[[International Herald Tribune]] |date=January 6, 2005 |accessdate = May 25, 2017 }} ===Notable cases=== {{Main|List of cases of Attorney General Eliot Spitzer}} In addition to prosecutions and civil actions in the financial sector, Spitzer pursued cases in both state and federal courts involving pollution, entertainment, technology, prostitution, corruption, occupational safety and health. ===Loan investigation controversy=== The New York State Senate Investigations committee considered investigating a controversial multi-million dollar loan the governor's father [[Bernard Spitzer]] gave him when he ran for attorney general in 1998, a loan the younger Spitzer paid back.Dicker, Fredric. [http://www.nypost.com/seven/07232007/news/columnists/gop_puts_heat_on_eliots_5m_loan_columnists_fredric_u__dicker.htm "GOP PUTS HEAT ON ELIOT'S $5M LOAN"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819121835/http://www.nypost.com/seven/07232007/news/columnists/gop_puts_heat_on_eliots_5m_loan_columnists_fredric_u__dicker.htm |date=August 19, 2007 }}, ''[[New York Post]]'', July 23, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. Senate Investigations Committee chairman [[George Winner]] told the ''New York Post'' that subpoenas should be used to find out about the loans.{{cite news |title=State Senate GOP Seek Spitzer Loan Records |agency=Associated Press | date=July 23, 2007}}{{verify source|date=February 2013}} Winner wrote to Senate Elections Committee chairman Senator [[Joseph Griffo]] that an article profiling Spitzer in ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine "outlined what may have been a willful effort by Eliot Spitzer and his father to circumvent campaign-contribution limits in New York state law and then conceal their actions." In 1998, Spitzer claimed that he secured the $5 million loan by [[mortgage loan|mortgaging]] apartments his father had given him, but later revealed that his father was paying off the loans and, therefore, financing his campaign. ==2006 campaign== {{Main|New York gubernatorial election, 2006}} [[File:Spitzer-on-stage (292269882).jpg|thumb|Spitzer celebrating on Election Night]] On December 8, 2004, Spitzer announced his intention to seek the Democratic nomination for governor of New York. While long rumored, Spitzer's announcement was unusually early—nearly two years before the election. As a result of Spitzer's relative speed in bringing state Democrats to his side, he gained the respect of Democratic leaders nationwide. [[New Mexico]] Governor [[Bill Richardson]] dubbed Spitzer the "future of the Democratic Party" at a fund raiser held in June 2005 for Spitzer's gubernatorial campaign.{{cite news |title=Richardson praises Eliot Spitzer as "future" of Democratic Party |url=http://www.freenewmexican.com/news/14376.html |agency=Associated Press |date=June 2, 2005 |accessdate=November 4, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060813225348/http://www.freenewmexican.com/news/14376.html |archivedate = August 13, 2006}} In January 2006, Spitzer selected New York State Senate minority leader [[David Paterson]] as his choice for lieutenant governor and running mate. After announcing his candidacy, Spitzer was endorsed by numerous New Yorkers, including state Comptroller [[Alan Hevesi]] and two former New York City mayors, [[David Dinkins]] and [[Ed Koch]]. On May 30, 2006, Spitzer and Paterson won the endorsement of the New York State Democratic party.{{cite news |first=Danny |last=Hakim |title=Convention Notebook; Controversy Over Ground Zero's Fate Is Front and Center in Buffalo |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/05/30/nyregion/30cnd-convene.html |work=The New York Times |date=May 30, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2006}} A June 2006 [[Quinnipiac University Polling Institute]] poll showed him leading [[Nassau County, New York|Nassau]] [[county executive]] [[Thomas Suozzi]] 76–13 percent.{{cite news|title=Faso Convention Bubble Goes Flat in Gov Race, Quinnipiac University New York State Poll Finds; Spitzer Still Has 40-Point Lead Over Faso, Suozzi |url=http://www.quinnipiac.edu/x11373.xml?ReleaseID=928 |agency=Associated Press |date=June 21, 2006 |accessdate=November 4, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060909075213/https://www.quinnipiac.edu/x11373.xml?ReleaseID=928 |archivedate=September 9, 2006 }} On July 25, 2006, he faced Suozzi in a gubernatorial debate held at [[Pace University]] in Manhattan, discussing issues such as [[public authority|public authorities]] and [[Medicaid]].{{cite news|first=Josh|last=Robin|title=Spitzer, Suozzi Face-Off in Sole Gubernatorial Debate|url=http://www.ny1.com/ny1/content/index.jsp?&aid=61294&search_result=1&stid=3|publisher=[[NY1]]|date=July 25, 2006|accessdate=November 4, 2006}} When asked about [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]], Spitzer stated that he disagrees with [[medical marijuana|medicinal use]] of the drug, claiming that other medicines were more effective.{{cite news|first=Geoffrey|last=Gray|title=Spitzer Chokes on Pot Deal|url=http://newyorkmetro.com/news/intelligencer/18863/|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|date=August 14, 2006|accessdate=November 4, 2006}} In the Democratic primary held on September 12, 2006, Spitzer handily defeated Suozzi, securing his party's nomination with 81 percent of the vote. On October 5, Spitzer addressed the [[Empire State Pride Agenda]] and declared that he would work as governor to legalize gay marriage in New York.{{cite news|first=Danny|last=Hakim|title=Spitzer Vows to Push for Gay Marriage|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/07/nyregion/07gays.html |work=The New York Times|date=October 7, 2006|accessdate=November 4, 2006}} Spitzer was elected governor on November 7, 2006, when he defeated Republican [[John Faso]] and [[Libertarian Party of New York|Libertarian]] John Clifton, among others, with 69 percent of the vote. He won with the largest margin of victory ever in a New York gubernatorial race.Plotch, Philip Mark. ''Politics Across the Hudson: The Tappan Zee Megaproject''. A public ceremony was held at 1 p.m. on the same day that featured brass and percussion players from the [[Empire State Youth Orchestra]].{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Cooper |title=Amid Champagne and Cheers, Spitzer Is Sworn in as Governor |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/01/nyregion/01inaug.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 1, 2007 }} Bucking tradition, the ceremony was held outdoors – the first outdoor inauguration ceremony in New York for over a century.[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aVp7olerYxwc&refer=home "Spitzer, Sworn in as New York Governor, Vows Historic Reform"], Bloomberg, January 1, 2007. Retrieved July 27, 2007. After taking the oath of office, he attended a concert at the [[Times Union Center]] in his honor, headlined by [[James Taylor]] and [[Natalie Merchant]]. ===Legislative measures supported=== * [[Jonathan's Law]] – In May 2007 Governor Spitzer signed this legislation concerning parental and guardian access to files and records concerning their children and child abuse investigations. ===Roadblocks to reform=== [[File:EliotSpitzerApril24.07.jpg|thumb|left|Spitzer speaking in April 2007]] Spitzer's reform-based platform, and his pledge "to change the ethics of [[Albany, New York|Albany]]", hit an early roadblock when his ideas on how to fill vacancies in the executive department were defeated by the state legislature. According to the [[New York State Constitution]], it is the duty of the state legislature to fill executive vacancies. The governor was criticized as unreasonable for admonishing the legislature when it took constitutional actions. The appointment of state assemblyman [[Thomas DiNapoli]] to succeed the disgraced [[Alan Hevesi]] as [[New York State Comptroller]] was a serious blow to the new governor. Spitzer had backed an outside panel to draft a list of qualified candidates; the legislature resisted Spitzer's desires when these included no legislators.{{cite news |first=Michael |last=Cooper |title=Legislators Pick a Comptroller, Defying Spitzer. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/08/nyregion/08comptroller.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 8, 2007 |accessdate=February 12, 2007 }} Some Assembly Democrats were alienated over the incident, and questioned Spitzer's refusal of extending [[patronage]] to party members seeking local{{Vague|date=January 2010}} political appointments.{{Verify source|date=January 2010}} Spitzer's choice was New York City Finance Commissioner [[Martha Stark]], who was selected by a panel that consisted of former State Comptroller [[Edward Regan]], former State Comptroller [[Carl McCall]] and former New York City Comptroller [[Harrison J. Goldin]]. On February 7, 2007, when the Legislature voted, Stark was one of two names put into nomination, along with Assemblyman Thomas DiNapoli of Long Island, Assembly Leader [[Sheldon Silver]]'s choice. The final vote was 150 for DiNapoli and 56 for Stark. Stark's main support came from Democrats in the Senate, along with Republicans in both chambers.{{Verify source|date=January 2010}} Spitzer traveled to the home districts of Democratic assemblymen William B. Magnarelli and George S. Latimer (in [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]] and [[Westchester County]] respectively), and publicly criticized them for their votes on DiNapoli; he had plans to exert similar pressure on other of his party's legislators.Fenner, Austin and Mahoney, Joe. {{cite web |url=http://nydailynews.com/front/v-pfriendly/story/497049p-418915c.html |title=Bulldog Spitzer rips pol |accessdate=June 1, 2016}}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}, ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'', February 12, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007.Hakim, Danny. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/13/nyregion/13spitzer.html "On Tour to Talk Up Budget Plan, Spitzer Stays on Attack"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 13, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. One of Spitzer's key campaign pledges was to reform the state budget process. While the state did pass a budget on schedule in 2007, the ultimate results fell short of what many reformers hoped Spitzer would achieve. The ''[[New York Post]]'' opined, "Spitzer promised reform, and delivered something completely different" and termed the budget itself "bitterly disappointing."[http://www.nypost.com/seven/04032007/postopinion/editorials/eliots_education_editorials_.htm "ELIOT'S EDUCATION"], ''[[New York Post]]'', April 3, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. Spitzer's budget quickly turned into a deficit, as by the end of October it was projected the state would run a deficit exceeding $4 billion for the year. During Spitzer's first year the state payroll increased, aggravating the budget problem.{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/buffalo/stories/2007/12/10/daily37.html |title=State payroll jumps with Spitzer | date=December 13, 2007}} Despite increasing the public sector payroll, in late 2007 New York State started leading the nation in lost jobs. The 2008–09 budget includes measures to counter financial effects of the crisis in the financial sector starting in the second half of 2007.{{cite web|url=http://publications.budget.state.ny.us/eBudget0809/ExecutiveBudgetPresentation2008-09Final.pdf |title=2008–09 Executive Budget, Eliot Spitzer |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311190720/http://publications.budget.state.ny.us/eBudget0809/ExecutiveBudgetPresentation2008-09Final.pdf |archivedate=March 11, 2008 }}. Retrieved March 14, 2008. Spitzer was criticized by members of the [[New York State Legislature]] for failing to compromise on issues during his first few months as governor. In one exchange, according to the ''New York Post'', Spitzer told New York State Assembly Minority Leader [[James Tedisco]]: "Listen, I'm a f - - -king [hyphens ''sic'' on ''Post'' website] steamroller and I'll roll over you and anybody else", although they reported that neither party had provided the confirmation the ''Post'' sought.Dicker, Fredric. [http://www.nypost.com/seven/02012007/news/regionalnews/full_steam_ahead_for_spunky_spitz_regionalnews_fredric_u__dicker_________state_editor.htm Full Steam Ahead for Spunky Spitz] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724141217/http://www.nypost.com/seven/02012007/news/regionalnews/full_steam_ahead_for_spunky_spitz_regionalnews_fredric_u__dicker_________state_editor.htm |date=July 24, 2008 }}, ''[[New York Post]]'', February 1, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. Spitzer's reputation as a "steamroller" was shared by a plurality of New Yorkers in a [[Quinnipiac University poll]], but by a 3 to 1 margin they believed the tactic had been unsuccessful and had only added to political gridlock.{{cite web|url=http://www.quinnipiac.edu/x1318.xml?ReleaseID=1107|title=Spitzer Knew About Troopergate And Should Testify, New York State Voters Tell Quinnipiac University Poll; Comptroller Should Share Pension Decisions, Voters Say}} Tedisco later accused Spitzer of cutting $300,000 of state funding for health care and education grants in the [[Schenectady]] area as retaliation for Tedisco's opposition to the Spitzer plan to allow [[illegal immigrants]] New York State driver's licenses.[[Fredric U. Dicker|Dicker, Fredric U.]], [http://www.nypost.com/seven/10172007/news/regionalnews/young__poor_hit_hardest.htm Young & Poor Hit Hardest], ''[[New York Post]]''. Tedisco accused the Governor of "dirty tricks" and "bullying".[http://www.cbs6albany.com/news/spitzer_1252204___article.html/tedisco_governor.html Tedisco Accuses Spitzer of 'Dirty Tricks,' 'Bullying'] October 17, 2007 In the wake of the [[Eliot Spitzer political surveillance controversy|political surveillance controversy]] involving Bruno, Spitzer was accused of pandering to special interest groups to solidify his base of support. "The governor who took office vowing to clean up Albany has lost so much public support that he is reduced to feathering the nest of the unions and other liberals," wrote Michael Goodwin of the ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]''.Goodwin, Michael, [http://www.nydailynews.com/opinions/2007/09/30/2007-09-30_cornered_by_troopergate_spitzer_is_showi.html Cornered by Troopergate, Spitzer is showing his desperation], ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]''. In February 2008, ''The Washington Post'' published an [[op-ed]] written by Spitzer in which he criticized the [[Presidency of George W. Bush|Bush Administration]] for inhibiting States from pursuing [[predatory lending|predatory lender]]s.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/02/13/AR2008021302783.html|title=Predatory Lenders' Partner in Crime; How the Bush Administration Stopped the States From Stepping in to Help Consumers|last=Spitzer|first=Elliot |date=February 14, 2008|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=September 30, 2008}} ===Proposal to legalize same-sex marriage=== In April 2007, Spitzer proposed a bill that would legalize [[same-sex marriage in New York]]. State Senate Majority Leader [[Joe Bruno]] announced his opposition to the proposal.{{cite news |title=Spitzer unveils gay marriage bill; Senate leader balks|agency=Associated Press |date=April 27, 2007}} This legislation passed in the [[New York State Assembly|State Assembly]] on June 19, 2007, but was denied in the [[New York State Senate|State Senate]] and was returned to the Assembly.{{cite web|url=http://assembly.state.ny.us/leg/?bn=A08590|title=Bill Summary – A08590}} === Use of State Police for surveillance / "Troopergate" === {{Main|Eliot Spitzer political surveillance controversy}} On July 23, 2007, [[New York Attorney General]] [[Andrew Cuomo]]'s office admonished the Spitzer administration for ordering the State Police to keep special records of Senate majority leader [[Joseph Bruno]]'s whereabouts when he traveled with police escorts in New York City.Hakim, Danny. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/23/nyregion/23cnd-spitzer.html?pagewanted=print "Spitzer's Staff Misused Police, Report Finds"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 23, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. A 57-page report issued by the Attorney General's office concluded that Spitzer engaged in creating media coverage concerning Senator Bruno's travel.{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Precious |title=Cuomo criticizes Spitzer for using State Police to monitor Bruno |publisher=The Buffalo News |date=July 23, 2007}} The investigation looked into both Bruno's travel and the Senate leader's allegation that Spitzer used State Police to spy on him.Gormley, Michael. [http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=3406517 "Report: NY Governor's Office Leaked Data"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', July 23, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080323032614/http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=3406517 |date=March 23, 2008 }} Cuomo concluded that "These e-mails show that persons in the governor's office did not merely produce records under a [[FOIL request]], but were instead engaged in planning and producing media coverage concerning Senator Bruno's travel on state aircraft before any [[FOIL request]] was made."{{cite web | author = Gormley, Michael | url = http://www.oneidadispatch.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=18620173&BRD=1709&PAG=461&dept_id=68844&rfi=6 | title = Spitzer aides linked to Bruno leaks | publisher = ''[[Observer-Dispatch|Utica Observer-Dispatch]]'' | quote = Cuomo concluded: "These e-mails show that persons in the governor's office did not merely produce records under a [[FOIL request]], but were instead engaged in planning and producing media coverage concerning Senator Bruno's travel on state aircraft before any [[FOIL request]] was made." | date = July 24, 2007 | accessdate = July 28, 2007 | deadurl = yes | archivedate = September 27, 2007 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927211135/http://www.oneidadispatch.com/site/news.cfm?newsid=18620173&BRD=1709&PAG=461&dept_id=68844&rfi=6 }}Faiola, Anthony. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/07/24/AR2007072401999.html "N.Y. Governor Moves to Limit Ethics Scandal"], ''[[The Washington Post]]'', Page A06, July 25, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. It also suggests that the governor's staff lied when they tried to explain what they had done and forced the State Police to go far beyond their normal procedures in documenting Bruno's whereabouts.Hakim, Danny. [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/24/nyregion/24governor.html "His Aura Faded Now, Spitzer Faces Bolder Enemies"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', July 23, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. The report cleared Bruno of any misuse of the state's air fleet, which had been alleged.Matthews, Cara. Spitzer subsequently announced that he would indefinitely suspend his communications director, Darren Dopp, and reassign another top official.Jochnowitz, Jay. {{cite web |url=http://timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=608323&category=&BCCode=HOME&newsdate=7%2F23%2F2007 |title="AG report faults Spitzer aides in Bruno scheme" |accessdate=2008-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514041000/http://timesunion.com/AspStories/story.asp?storyID=608323&category=&BCCode=HOME&newsdate=7%2F23%2F2007 |archivedate=May 14, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}, ''[[Times Union (Albany)|Albany Times-Union]]'', July 23, 2007. When questioned about his promise to bring ethical responsibility to state politics, Spitzer responded by saying "I will not tolerate this behavior", "ethics and accountability must and will remain rigorous in my administration," and that "I have always stated that I want ethics and integrity to be the hallmarks of my administration. That is why I requested that the State Inspector General review the allegations with respect to my office, and that is why we have fully cooperated with both inquiries." The investigations of the event, dubbed "Troopergate" by media outlets, were not affected by Spitzer's resignation.Freifeld, Karen. March 13, 2008. ===Driver's licenses for illegal immigrants=== {{Main|Eliot Spitzer drivers license controversy}} [[File:08 30 07 spitzer Clinton.jpg|thumb|left|Spitzer with [[Hillary Clinton]] in 2007]] On September 21, 2007, Spitzer issued an [[executive order]] directing that state offices allow illegal immigrants to be issued [[driver's license]]s effective December 2007.{{cite news |title=Department of Motor Vehicles Changes License Policy to Include More New Yorkers and Implements New Regime of Anti-Fraud Measures to Strengthen the Security of the System |url=http://www.ny.gov/governor/press/0921071.html |work=press release |publisher=Office of the Governor of New York |date=September 21, 2007 |accessdate=November 10, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071030132823/http://www.ny.gov/governor/press/0921071.html |archivedate = October 30, 2007}}{{cite news |first=Nina |last=Bernstein |title=Spitzer grants undocumented immigrants easier access to driver's licenses |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?pagewanted=all |work=The New York Times |date=September 22, 2007 |accessdate=November 14, 2007 }} Applicants for driver's licenses would not be required to prove legal immigration status and would be allowed to present a foreign passport as identification. After meeting with the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] in October 2007, Spitzer altered the plan so that licenses issued to migrant workers would look different from other licenses and that the new licenses would not allow access to airplanes and federal buildings.{{cite news |first=James T. |last=Madore |url=http://www.newsday.com/news/local/state/ny-usimmi095452806nov09,0,2841126.story|title=Spitzer defends license plan over Democrat fears |work=Newsday |date=November 9, 2007 |accessdate=November 10, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111145743/http://www.newsday.com/news/local/state/ny-usimmi095452806nov09,0,2841126.story |archivedate=November 11, 2007}} On October 21, 2007, the State Senate voted to oppose the Spitzer plan by a 39–19 vote.{{cite news |first=Nicholas |last=Confessore |title=Senate Votes to Stop Spitzer Plan to Give undocumented Immigrants Driver's Licenses |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/23/nyregion/23legislature.html |work=The New York Times |date=October 23, 2007 |accessdate=November 10, 2007 }}{{cite news |first=Nicholas |last=Confessore |title=Why Some Democrats Defected on Spitzer Driver's License Plan |url=http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2007/10/23/looking-at-the-state-senates-democratic-defectors/ |work=The New York Times |date=October 23, 2007 |accessdate=November 10, 2007 }} Eight Democrats from moderate districts broke with Spitzer on the vote. After the vote, ''[[The New York Times]]'' called this issue "Mr. Spitzer's single most unpopular decision since he took office." Following the State Senate's vote, Spitzer revised his plan again, proposing the issuance of a third type of driver's license. This driver's license would be available only to United States citizens who are New York State residents, and would be valid for crossing the [[Canada–United States border|Canada–US border]].{{cite news |first=Nicholas |last=Confessore |title=Visa data to be included on driver's licenses again |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/31/nyregion/31license.html |work=The New York Times |date=October 31, 2007 |accessdate=November 14, 2007 }} Spitzer also announced that the expiration dates of temporary [[visa (document)|visa]]s would be printed on the driver's licenses of individuals living in the country with them. On November 14, the day following the release of a poll showing the proposal as extremely unpopular with voters, Spitzer announced he would withdraw the plan, acknowledging that it would never be implemented.{{cite news |first=Devlin |last=Barrett |title=Spitzer Dropping His Driver's License Plan |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/14/nyregion/14spitzer.html |work=The New York Times |date=November 14, 2007 |accessdate=November 14, 2007 }}{{cite news |first=Sasha |last=Issenberg |title=Clinton backs N.Y. driver's license plan for undocumented immigrants |url=http://www.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2007/11/01/clinton_backs_ny_drivers_license_plan_for_illegal_immigrants/ |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=November 1, 2007 |accessdate=November 10, 2007 }}{{cite web|url=http://wcbstv.com/local/spitzer.immigrant.drivers.2.567070.html|title=Just Call Him...Gov. Flip-Flop|accessdate=November 26, 2007|last=Kramer|first=Marcia|date=November 15, 2007|work=Local News|publisher=[[WCBS-TV]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071114221917/http://wcbstv.com/local/spitzer.immigrant.drivers.2.567070.html |archivedate = November 14, 2007}} The decision drew derision from the press, as the [[Associated Press]] termed this reversal a "surrender."{{cite news |first=Devlin |last=Barrett |url=|title=Gov. Spitzer Surrenders on License Fight |agency=Associated Press |date=November 15, 2007}} [[WCBS-TV]] labeled him "Governor Flip-Flop." State Senator [[Rubén Díaz, Sr.|Rubén Díaz]] of the Bronx said he was "betrayed" by Spitzer's abandonment of the plan.{{cite news |first=Kennth |last=Lovett |author2=Geoff Earle |title=Hill's 'Stand?' 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080308124229/http://www.legislativegazette.com/read_more.php?story=2752 |archivedate=March 8, 2008 }} ===Prostitution scandal=== {{Main|Eliot Spitzer prostitution scandal}} On March 10, 2008, ''The New York Times'' reported that Spitzer had patronized a high-priced [[Escort agency|escort service]] called Emperors Club VIP{{cite }} and met for two hours with a $1,000-an-hour [[Call girl#Call girls and celebrities|call girl]]. "Madam" |date=March 5, 2008 |work=Washington City Paper |first=Erik |last=Wemple }}{{cite news|url=http://www.wnbc.com/news/15555281/detail.html |title=Spitzer apologizes to family, public |accessdate=March 10, 2008 |date=March 10, 2008 |publisher=[[WNBC]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312043747/http://www.wnbc.com/news/15555281/detail.html |archivedate=March 12, 2008 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2008/0306082emperor6.html |title=Online Hooker Ring Busted |date=March 6, 2008 |publisher=The Smoking Gun |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312163406/http://www.thesmokinggun.com/archive/years/2008/0306082emperor6.html |archivedate=March 12, 2008 |df=mdy }} During a six month span, Spitzer had at least seven or eight liaisons with women from the agency and paid more than $15,000.Kessler, Robert. [[WNBC]]. March 11, 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080312093827/http://www.wnbc.com/politics/15562646/detail.html |date=March 12, 2008 }} According to published reports, investigators alleged that Spitzer paid up to $80,000 for prostitutes over a period of several years while he was attorney general, and later as governor.{{cite news |title=Spitzer resigns amid sex scandal |first=Sheldon |last=Alberts |work=Canwest News Service |publisher=The Gazette |date=March 12, 2008 |url=http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=1722ada9-2541-4484-912a-b41d794f063f |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080315133804/http://www.canada.com/montrealgazette/news/story.html?id=1722ada9-2541-4484-912a-b41d794f063f |archivedate=March 15, 2008 |df=mdy }}[http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-D8VC6EG00.html "Disgraced NY Governor won't Need New Job"]. Associated Press, March 12, 2008[http://www.nypost.com/seven/03122008/news/regionalnews/80g_addicted_to_love_gov_101541.htm 80G 'Addicted to Love' Gov"], ''New York Post'', March 12, 2008. Spitzer first drew the attention of federal investigators when his bank reported suspicious money transfers under the [[anti-money laundering]] provisions of the [[Bank Secrecy Act]] and the [[Patriot Act]].Hosenball, Mark (March 15, 2008). [http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/2008/03/15/unintended-consequences.html "Unintended consequences: Spitzer got snagged by the fine print of the Patriot Act"]. ''Newsweek''. The resulting investigation was triggered by the belief that Spitzer might have been hiding bribe proceeds and led to the discovery of the prostitution ring.{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/story?id=4424507&page=1|title=It Wasn't the Sex; Suspicious $$ Transfers Led to Spitzer|author=Brian Ross|date=March 10, 2008}} ===Resignation=== In the wake of the revelations, Spitzer announced on March 12, 2008, that he would resign his post as governor at noon on March 17, 2008, amid threats of his [[impeachment]] by state lawmakers. Spitzer said at a news conference in Manhattan: {{quote|I cannot allow for my private failings to disrupt the people's work. Over the course of my public life, I have insisted{{emdash}}I believe correctly{{emdash}}that people take responsibility for their conduct. I can and will ask no less of myself. For this reason, I am resigning from the office of governor.{{cite web |url=http://www.amny.com/news/local/wire/politics/ny-bc-ny-spitzer-resignatio0312mar12,0,7214884.story |title=Text of Governor Spitzer's resignation letter |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080320201755/http://www.amny.com/news/local/wire/politics/ny-bc-ny-spitzer-resignatio0312mar12,0,7214884.story |archivedate=March 20, 2008 |df=mdy-all }}}} Spitzer's lieutenant governor, [[David Paterson]], succeeded him as governor of New York State and served the remaining {{sfrac|2|3|4}} years of Spitzer's four year term. ==Post-resignation== ===Prostitution scandal developments=== On July 16, 2008, ''[[The New York Times]]'' published an article that explained how Spitzer used campaign funds to pay for two [[Mayflower Hotel]] bookings, $411.06 apiece, where he was alleged to have met with prostitutes. While it remains unclear if Spitzer stayed in the hotel on the nights he booked, ''The Times'' has stated that Spitzer met with prostitutes in early 2008. Spitzer declined to comment on the issue.{{cite news |title=Spitzer Charged Campaign for Hotel Bills, Raising Question About His Funds |first=Danny |last=Hakim |work=The New York Times |date=June 16, 2008 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/16/nyregion/16spitzer.html }} In November 2008, prosecutors who were in charge of the case announced that Spitzer would not face criminal charges for his involvement in the sex ring. They cited that no evidence of misuse of public funds was found and therefore it would not serve the public interest to press charges against Spitzer, who offered an apology for his conduct, saying "I appreciate the impartiality and thoroughness of the investigation by the U.S. Attorney's Office, and I acknowledge and accept responsibility for the conduct it disclosed."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/07/nyregion/07spitzer.html |title=No Federal Prostitution Charges for Spitzer |last=Hakim|first=Danny|author2=William K. Rashbaum |date=November 6, 2008|work=The New York Times|accessdate=November 15, 2008}} ===Teaching=== In September 2009, Spitzer joined the faculty of the [[City College of New York]] as an adjunct instructor of political science and taught an undergraduate course called "Law and Public Policy."{{cite news| url=http://www1.ccny.cuny.edu/prospective/humanities/rifkind/upload/Spitzer-Flyer-2.pdf|title=A Special Private Conversation with Gov. Eliot Spitzer| date=April 28, 2011| publisher=City College of New York|accessdate=August 23, 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Peters|first1=Jeremy|title=Eliot Spitzer Has a New Job: Adjunct Instructor of Political Science|accessdate=29 September 2016|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/03/nyregion/03spitzer.html|work=The New York Times|date=2 September 2009}} === Media appearances === Spitzer continued to make public appearances and engage in media commitments following his resignation. ''[[The Washington Post]]'' published a Spitzer opinion piece in November 2008 conveying his analysis of the [[financial crisis of 2008]] and suggested remedies. Spitzer concluded the piece by saying that he hoped the Obama Administration would make the right policy choices, "although mistakes I made in my private life now prevent me from participating in these issues as I have in the past."{{cite news |title=How to Ground the Street|first=Spitzer |last=Eliot|work=The Washington Post|date=November 16, 2008|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/13/AR2008111303634.html}} Spitzer became a regular columnist for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' magazine and in December, 2008 ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' published the first of a new series of columns by Spitzer dedicated to the economy.{{cite news |title=Too Big Not To Fail |first=Eliot |last=Spitzer |publisher=Slate.com |date=December 3, 2008 |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2205995/ }} On August 22, 2011, ''The New York Times'' reported that Spitzer has been sued for a combined $90 million over an August 22, 2010 ''Slate'' column about Wall Street firm [[Marsh & McLennan]] by two former executives of the company, claiming that they were libeled by the column.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/23/business/media/spitzer-and-slate-face-lawsuit-over-column-on-wall-street.html| title=Spitzer and Slate Face Defamation Lawsuit| first=Jeremy W.| last=Peters| newspaper=The New York Times| date=August 22, 2011| accessdate=August 23, 2011}} The lawsuit by one of the executives was dismissed the following year.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/29/nyregion/federal-judge-dismisses-libel-lawsuit-against-ex-gov-spitzer.html | title=Federal Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Ex-Gov. Spitzer | first=Thomas| last=Kaplan| newspaper=The New York Times| date=September 28, 2012| accessdate=December 21, 2012}} Spitzer took on various public speaking arrangements, beginning with a discussion with the New York chapter of the [[Entrepreneurs' Organization]] on June 17, 2009.{{cite news|title=An Intimate Evening With Eliot Spitzer |first=Joseph |last=Steinberg |publisher=EO-NY |date=April 7, 2009 |url=http://www.eonyc.org/index.php?section=events&evtid=704 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422151624/http://www.eonyc.org/index.php?section=events |archivedate=April 22, 2009 }} He also made a number of television appearances in 2009 and 2010, including ''[[Real Time with Bill Maher]]'' and ''[[Campbell Brown (TV series)|Campbell Brown]]'' (CNN program), as well as appearing as a substitute anchor on [[MSNBC]]. On June 24, 2010, [[CNN]] announced that Spitzer would be joining the network to host a "round-table" discussion program alongside center-right commentator [[Kathleen Parker]]. ''Parker Spitzer'', compared by some media outlets to the defunct ''[[Crossfire (U.S. TV program)|Crossfire]]'', replaced ''[[Campbell Brown (TV series)|Campbell Brown]]'' in the 8:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone|ET]] timeslot on weeknights starting in October.{{Cite news | title = US: Former governor Eliot Spitzer joins CNN | work = The Spy Report | publisher = Media Spy | date = June 25, 2010 | url = http://www.mediaspy.org/report/2010/06/25/us-former-governor-eliot-spitzer-joins-cnn/ | accessdate = June 25, 2010}} In February 2011, CNN announced that Parker was leaving the show, which was renamed ''[[In the Arena]]'' on February 28, 2011. On July 6, 2011, CNN announced it was canceling ''In the Arena'' and shifting ''[[Anderson Cooper 360°]]'' to the 8 p.m. time slot.{{cite news| url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/06/cnn-cancels-in-the-arena-with-eliot-spitzer/| date=July 6, 2011| title=CNN Cancels 'In the Arena' With Eliot Spitzer| first=Brian| last=Stelter| newspaper= The New York Times| accessdate=August 23, 2011}} On March 30, 2012, Spitzer joined Al Gore's cable television network, [[Current TV]], in the wake of the sudden firing of [[Keith Olbermann]] from the network, and immediately began hosting his own program ''[[Viewpoint with Eliot Spitzer]]''.[[Al Gore|Gore, Al]], and [[Joel Hyatt]], [http://current.com/blog/93722062_open-letter-to-the-viewers-of-current.htm "Open letter to the viewers of Current"], Current TV, March 30, 2012. On January 6, 2013, Spitzer announced that he had left both ''Viewpoint'' and Current TV, and that he would not be joining Current TV in its latest venture with [[Al Jazeera]]. "Moving forward, their mission will be different," he said. He also stated: "For me, journalism has been more a matter of projecting a particular approach to covering policies, to covering issues. It was a continuation of what I tried to do in government. And that doesn't fit with their vision of what they are going to do."{{cite news|title=Eliot Spitzer Ends His Show on Current TV|url=http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/06/eliot-spitzer-end-his-show-on-current-tv/|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 7, 2013|first=Brian|last=Stelter|date=January 6, 2013}} ===2013 campaign for NYC Comptroller=== {{Main|New York City Comptroller Election, 2013}} On July 7, 2013, Spitzer announced he was running for [[New York City Comptroller]], and would start a petition the following day. 3,750 valid signatures from registered voters from his party were required by July 11 to register for the race but Spitzer was able to submit over 27,000 signatures to the city Board of Elections before the deadline.{{cite news|title=Spitzer Submits Signatures to Get on NYC Ballot|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/spitzer-submits-signatures-get-nyc-ballot|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=July 12, 2013}} Spitzer commented that he was asking for forgiveness, and hopeful that voters could forgive him.{{cite news|title=Asking Forgiveness, Spitzer Will Run for City Comptroller |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/08/nyregion/spitzer-seeks-ballot-for-city-comptrollers-race.html|first=Michael|last=Barbaro|first2=David W.|last2=Chen|work=The New York Times|date=July 7, 2013|accessdate=July 8, 2013}} Eliot Spitzer lost the primary on September 10, 2013 to [[Scott Stringer]].{{cite news|title=Live Results: New York City Primary Elections|url=http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/2013/nyc-primary-results?rr|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=September 10, 2013|first=Aaron|last=Bycoffe}} ===Investing=== In 2012, Spitzer became an investor in [[TipRanks]], an Israeli financial technology start-up company that ranks Wall Street analysts. He became a member of the company's board of directors. ===2016 extortion scandal=== In February 2016, Spitzer was investigated by the New York City Police Department after being accused of assault by Svetlana Travis-Zakharova, a woman from Russia, in an incident that supposedly occurred at the [[Plaza Hotel]] on February 13, 2016. The New York Daily News reported Spitzer had been accused of attacking the woman, who tried to kill herself by slitting her wrists after the incident.{{Cite web|title = Ex-Gov. Spitzer being investigated for assaulting woman|url = http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/manhattan/ex-gov-spitzer-investigated-assaulting-woman-article-1.2531507|website = NY Daily News|access-date = 2016-02-15}} Ms. Travis subsequently recanted her accusations and no charges were filed.{{cite news|last1=McKinley|first1=Jesse|title=Eliot Spitzer Sues Woman Who Accused Him of Assault|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/16/nyregion/eliot-spitzer-sues-woman-who-accused-him-of-assault.html?_r=0|accessdate=29 September 2016|publisher=NewYorkTimes|date=15 July 2016}} Within a month, Travis − who left for Russia in February{{cite news|last1=Hays|first1=Tom|title=Woman charged in ex-NY governor extortion plot held on bail|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/3d85b54d4e9f485fa5f4b29a67de2385/woman-accused-trying-extort-money-ex-gov-spitzer|accessdate=12 October 2016|agency=Associated Press|date=October 12, 2016}} − turned from an alleged victim into a suspect. On October 10, she was arrested upon landing at [[JFK International Airport]]. On October 12, Travis-Zakharova, 26, faced state charges of grand larceny by extortion, while also being investigated for prostitution. Over two years, prosecutors claimed, she had collected around $50,000 from Spitzer in exchange for keeping "intimate details" of their relationship secret from his relatives. The money was allegedly deposited into a bank in Russia.{{cite news|last1=Ford|first1=James|title=Bail set at $1M for woman accused of extorting money from ex-NY Gov. Eliot Spitzer|url=http://pix11.com/2016/10/11/bail-set-at-1m-for-woman-accused-of-extorting-money-from-ex-ny-gov-eliot-spitzer/|accessdate=12 October 2016|agency=PIX11|date=October 11, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Brito|first1=Chris|title=Woman accused of extorting money from former NY Gov. Eliot Spitzer|url=http://pix11.com/2016/10/10/woman-arrested-for-trying-extort-money-from-former-ny-gov-eliot-spitzer-police-sources/|accessdate=12 October 2016|agency=PIX11|date=October 10, 2016}} Also on October 12, Travis faced forgery and identity theft charges, from an unrelated incident, after purportedly signing a high-end apartment lease under a different name, costing the victim − a 67-year-old New Jersey man − $18,000. The bail was set at $1 million. == Real estate career == Following his father's illness and death in 2014 and with politics behind him, Spitzer came to lead his family's real estate business, Spitzer Enterprises, despite having avoided the role for much of his life. Spitzer sold his company's apartments in [[The Corinthian (Manhattan)|The Corinthian]] and the [[Crown Building (Manhattan)|Crown Building]] for a large profit, which he used to fund a $700 million project of three waterfront buildings in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|South Williamsburg, Brooklyn]].{{Cite news |last1=Bagli |first1=Charles V. |title=Spitzer Charges Into His Family's Real Estate Business |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2015-06-15 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/16/nyregion/spitzer-charging-into-his-familys-real-estate-business.html |issn=0362-4331 |df=mdy-all }} ==Personal life== [[Silda Wall Spitzer|Silda Wall]] and Eliot Spitzer married on October 17, 1987, and together they have three daughters: Elyssa (b. 1990), Sarabeth (b. 1993), and Jenna (b. 1995).{{Cite news |url=https://nypost.com/2013/03/10/silda-spitzer-still-with-husband-eliot-five-years-after-luv-guv-scandal |work=[[New York Post]] |title=Silda Spitzer still with husband Eliot five years after 'Luv Guv' scandal |first=Maureen |last=Callahan |date=March 10, 2013}} On May 31, 2013, Spitzer and his wife were reported to be living apart.{{cite news |title=Eliot Spitzer & Wife Silda Living Apart Five Years After Cheating – Report |first=Christopher |last=Rogers |work=Hollywood Life |date=May 31, 2013 |url=http://hollywoodlife.com/2013/05/31/silda-eliot-spitzer-living-apart-cheating-ashely-dupre/ }} At the close of 2013, Spitzer and his wife announced the end of their marriage.{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/24/politics/eliot-spitzer-marriage |title=Eliot Spitzer and his wife announce the end of their marriage |first=Haley |last=Draznin |author2=Catherine E. Shoichet |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=December 24, 2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2013}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/12/25/former-ny-gov-eliot-spitzer-announces-end-his-marriage/ |title=Former NY gov Eliot Spitzer announces end of his marriage |date=December 25, 2013 |publisher=[[Fox News]] |agency=''[[New York Post]]'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131225211628/http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2013/12/25/former-ny-gov-eliot-spitzer-announces-end-his-marriage/ |archivedate=December 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 30, 2013}} Spitzer is alleged to have had a romantic affair with Lis Smith, a 31-year-old spokeswoman for then-New York City Mayor-elect [[Bill de Blasio]]. She had been Spitzer's spokeswoman during his 2013 run for comptroller.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/25/nyregion/spitzer-and-his-wife-say-their-marriage-is-over.html |work=[[The New York Times]] |title=Spitzer and His Wife Say Their Marriage is over |first=Michael M. |last=Grynbaum |date=December 24, 2013}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/01/19/nyregion/lis-smith-girl-bashed-out-of-a-job-in-mayors-office.html |work=The New York Times |title=A Tabloid Bashing, and a Lost Job With the Mayor |first=Ginia |last=Bellafante |date=January 17, 2014 |quote=Ms. Smith was prepared for the negative press attention she knew she would receive as Mr. Spitzer's girlfriend, she told me. 'But what has been so hurtful is that so much of the viciousness has come from women,' she said, citing not just the tabloids but a patronizingly maternal piece in Time citing the foolishness of her choice, as if erotic selection always conformed to rational sense.}} ==See also== * ''[[Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer]]'' - film about Spitzer * ''[[Inside Job (2010 film)|Inside Job]]''—documentary on the 2008 financial crisis * ''[[The Good Wife]] ''- fictional television drama partly inspired by events associated with Spitzer and his wife * ''[[Zipper (film)|Zipper]]'' - 2015 film, a political thriller that thinly dramatizes the Eliot Spitzer scandal. {{Portal bar|Biography|New York}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} Stewart, S. '''FAIR data''' are data which meet standards of [[findability]], [[accessibility]], [[interoperability]], and [[reusability]].<ref name="FAIR principles 2016">{{cite web |last1=Wilkinson |first1=Mark D. |last2=Dumontier |first2=Michel |last3=Aalbersberg |first3=IJsbrand Jan |last4=Appleton |first4=Gabrielle |last5=Axton |first5=Myles |last6=Baak |first6=Arie |last7=Blomberg |first7=Niklas |last8=Boiten |first8=Jan-Willem |last9=da Silva Santos |first9=Luiz Bonino |last10=Bourne |first10=Philip E. |last11=Bouwman |first11=Jildau |last12=Brookes |first12=Anthony J. |last13=Clark |first13=Tim |last14=Crosas |first14=Mercè |last15=Dillo |first15=Ingrid |last16=Dumon |first16=Olivier |last17=Edmunds |first17=Scott |last18=Evelo |first18=Chris T. |last19=Finkers |first19=Richard |last20=Gonzalez-Beltran |first20=Alejandra |last21=Gray |first21=Alasdair J.G. |last22=Groth |first22=Paul |last23=Goble |first23=Carole |last24=Grethe |first24=Jeffrey S. |last25=Heringa |first25=Jaap |last26=’t Hoen |first26=Peter A.C |last27=Hooft |first27=Rob |last28=Kuhn |first28=Tobias |last29=Kok |first29=Ruben |last30=Kok |first30=Joost |last31=Lusher |first31=Scott J. |last32=Martone |first32=Maryann E. |last33=Mons |first33=Albert |last34=Packer |first34=Abel L. |last35=Persson |first35=Bengt |last36=Rocca-Serra |first36=Philippe |last37=Roos |first37=Marco |last38=van Schaik |first38=Rene |last39=Sansone |first39=Susanna-Assunta |last40=Schultes |first40=Erik |last41=Sengstag |first41=Thierry |last42=Slater |first42=Ted |last43=Strawn |first43=George |last44=Swertz |first44=Morris A. |last45=Thompson |first45=Mark |last46=van der Lei |first46=Johan |last47=van Mulligen |first47=Erik |last48=Velterop |first48=Jan |last49=Waagmeester |first49=Andra |last50=Wittenburg |first50=Peter |last51=Wolstencroft |first51=Katherine |last52=Zhao |first52=Jun |last53=Mons |first53=Barend |title=The FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management and stewardship |website=Scientific Data |pages=160018 |language=En |doi=10.1038/sdata.2016.18 |url=https://www.nature.com/articles/sdata201618 |date=15 March 2016}}</ref> A March 2016 publication by a consortium of scientists and organizations called these the "FAIR Guiding Principles for scientific data management and stewardship", using FAIR as an acronym and making the concept easier to discuss.<ref name="FAIR principles 2016"/>
At the [[2016 G20 Hangzhou summit]], the [[G20]] leaders issued a statement endorsing the application of FAIR principles to research.<ref>{{cite web |author1=G20 leaders |title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - G20 Leaders’ Communique Hangzhou Summit |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_STATEMENT-16-2967_en.htm |website=europa.eu |publisher=European Commission |language=en |date=5 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=European Commission embraces the FAIR principles - Dutch Techcentre for Life Sciences |url=https://www.dtls.nl/2016/04/20/european-commission-allocates-e2-billion-to-make-research-data-fair/ |website=Dutch Techcentre for Life Sciences |date=20 April 2016}}</ref> [[File:Implementing FAIR Data Principles - The Role of Libraries.pdf|thumb|right|"Implementing FAIR Data Principles - The Role of Libraries", a guide]] The [[Association of European Research Libraries]] recommends the use of FAIR principles.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Association of European Research Libraries |title=Open Consultation on FAIR Data Action Plan - LIBER |url=https://libereurope.eu/blog/2018/07/13/fairdataconsultation/ |website=LIBER |date=13 July 2018}}</ref>
A 2017 paper by advocates of FAIR data reported that awareness of the FAIR concept was increasing among various researchers and institutes, but also, understanding of the concept was becoming confused as different people apply their own differing perspectives to it.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mons |first1=Barend |last2=Neylon |first2=Cameron |last3=Velterop |first3=Jan |last4=Dumontier |first4=Michel |last5=da Silva Santos |first5=Luiz Olavo Bonino |last6=Wilkinson |first6=Mark D. |title=Cloudy, increasingly FAIR; revisiting the FAIR Data guiding principles for the European Open Science Cloud |journal=Information Services & Use |date=7 March 2017 |volume=37 |issue=1 |pages=49–56 |doi=10.3233/ISU-170824}}</ref>
Guides on implementing FAIR data practices state that the cost of a [[data management plans]] in compliance with FAIR data practices should be 5% of the total research budget.<ref>{{cite web |author1=Science Europe |title=Funding research data management and related infrastructures |url=https://www.scienceeurope.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/SE-KE_Briefing_Paper_Funding_RDM.pdf |date=May 2016}}</ref>

'''Fair play for musicians''' is a full-page propaganda [[advertisement]] that was published on 7 December 2006 in the [[Financial Times]] newspaper calling on the [[UK]] Government to extend the existing 50 years [[copyright]] protection for sound recordings in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ppluk.com/ppl/ppl_cd.nsf/News20061206 |title=British musicians demand fair play on copyright term |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[Phonographic Performance Limited]] |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071009082025/http://www.ppluk.com/ppl/ppl_cd.nsf/News20061206 |archivedate = 9 October 2007}}</ref> It consisted of around 4,500 names in small print filling the full page and its style was consistent with other newspaper [[petitions]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/suw/320393547/in/set-72157594416637345 |title=I see dead people 1 |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[Flickr]]}}</ref> The text "fair play for musicians" appeared in large red type over the list of names. In the centre of the page a box contained the text: :"We call upon the UK Government to support the extension of copyright in sound recordings." At the bottom of the page the following text appeared: :"On behalf of over 3,500 record companies and 40,000 performers"
The 'fair play for musicians' advertisement was viewed as a direct response to the [[Gowers Review]] published by the [[British Government]] on 6 December 2006 which recommended the retention of the 50 year protection for sound recordings.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6216152.stm |title=Musicians sign copyright advert |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] | date=7 December 2006}}</ref> The advertisement was organised by [[Phonographic Performance Limited]] as another element of their campaign for retrospective copyright term extension.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.openrightsgroup.org/2006/12/12/i-see-dead-people/ |title=I see dead people |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[Open Rights Group]]}}</ref>
The advertisement was controversial as it was seen as another step in a protracted campaign to influence British Government policy, and gave rise to worldwide media coverage,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/12/07/gowers_europe/ |title=Music industry will take copyright battle to Europe |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[The Register]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2006/dec/09/comment.music |title=They live like aristocrats. Now they think like them |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[The Guardian]] | location=London | first=Marina | last=Hyde | date=9 December 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,20896898-913,00.html |title=Rockers push copyright |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=NEWS.com.au | date=8 December 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C00E5DD1731F93BA35751C1A9609C8B63 |title=Arts, Briefly |accessdate=17 November 2008 |work=[[The New York Times]] | date=8 December 2006 | first=Lawrence | last=Van Gelder}}</ref> which was unusual for issues of copyright term policy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.technollama.co.uk/musician-revolt |title=Musician revolt? | first=Andres | last=Guadamuz |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[TechnoLlama]]}}</ref> The advertisement's inclusions of a number of deceased musicians raised suspicions that it was not a genuine representation of the wishes of the musicians listed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lessig.org/blog/2006/12/ok_so_im_wrong.html |title=Ok, so I'm wrong |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=[[Lawrence Lessig]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081106203057/http://lessig.org/blog/2006/12/ok_so_im_wrong.html |archivedate=6 November 2008 |df= }}</ref> Prominent law professor [[Lawrence Lessig]] criticised the advertisement for being misleading and declared the date of its publication, December 7, was "a date which will live in infamy."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lessig.org/blog/2006/12/good_days_and_then_bad.html |title=good days and then bad |accessdate=17 November 2008 |publisher=Lawrence Lessig}}</ref> The date is the same as [[Pearl Harbor]] attack and Lessig was alluding to [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]'s famous statement.
