The '''United Arab Emirates Five''' are five activists who were arrested on April 2011 on charges of breaking [[United Arab Emirates]] law of [[defamation]] by insulting head of states, namely UAE president [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]], vice president [[Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum]], and Abu Dhabi crown prince [[Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] through running an anti-government website that express anti-government views and slandered the head of states.
The five arrested activists were:<ref name=AI1>{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news-and-updates/uae-end-trial-activists-charged-insulting-officials-2011-07-17 |title=UAE: End Trial of Activists Charged with Insulting Officials |author= |date=17 July 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref>
*Nasser bin Ghaith; an Emirati economist and lecturer at the [[Abu Dhabi]] branch of the [[Paris-Sorbonne University]]. *[[Ahmed Mansoor]]; an Emirati engineer, a blogger and a human rights activist. *Fahad Salim Dalk; an Emirati online activist. *Hassan Ali al-Khamis; an Emirati online activist . *[[Ahmed Abdul Khaleq]]; a [[bedoon]] online activist.
On 27 November 2011, bin Ghaith, Dalk, al-Khamis, and Khaleq were sentenced to two years' imprisonment, and Mansoor to three years of imprisonment for being the main architect and mastermind of the website.<ref name=AJ>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111128135953601809.html |title=UAE pardons jailed activists |author= |date=28 November 2011 |work= |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> However, the following day, the five received a presidential pardon from Sheikh Khalifa bin Zayed and were released.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15922492 |title=Five jailed UAE activists 'receive presidential pardon' |author= |date=28 November 2011 |work= |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref>
==Arrests== Inspired by the growing momentum of the pro-democracy [[Arab Spring]], Emirati activists began to be more vocal in their opposition to the [[UAE government]] in early 2011. Bin Ghaith, an "outspoken economics professor", was arrested on 11 April for his call for "democratic and economic reforms".<ref name=BBC1>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13043270 |title=UAE arrests democracy activists |author= |date=11 April 2011 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> Mansoor, an engineer, blogger, and member of [[Human Rights Watch]], was arrested the same day for signing a petition in favor of an elected parliament,<ref name=BBC1 /> and Dalk, al-Khamis, and Khaleq were detained for their online activities before the end of the month.<ref name=AI1/> Following their arrests, UAE government-controlled media reported that the five were "religious extremists" and [[Iran]]ian foreign agents.<ref name=O />
Their arrests received immediate international attention, with continuing coverage in the [[BBC News]],<ref name=BBC1 /><ref name=BBC2>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-14192201 |title=UAE activists plead not guilty to insulting rulers |author= |date=18 July 2011 |work= |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9F0CE5DE1139F932A25757C0A9679D8B63 |title=Developments Across North Africa and the Middle East |author= |date=11 April 2011 |work= |publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref><ref name=NYT>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/30/world/middleeast/30iht-M30-UAE-POLITICS.html |title=Tensions Beneath the Stability in the U.A.E. |author=Angela Giuffrida |date=29 June 2011 |work= |publisher=''The New York Times'' |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> and various other media. [[Amnesty International]] designated the five [[prisoners of conscience]] and called for their immediate and unconditional release,<ref name=AI1 /> recruiting comedians and writers to lobby for their cause at the 2011 [[Edinburgh Festival]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/aug/07/amnesty-uae-activists-edinburgh-festival |title=Comedians and writers lead Amnesty campaign to free jailed UAE activists |author=Severin Carrell |date=7 August 2011 |work= |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |accessdate=26 January 2012}}</ref> The organization also coined the name "The UAE Five" to refer to the men, which was later adopted by some media sources.<ref name=O>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/sep/11/amnesty-urgent-action-uae-five |title=The UAE Five: Amnesty urgent action |author= |date=10 September 2011 |work= |publisher=''[[The Observer]]'' |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> [[Human Rights Watch]] condemned the trial as "an attack on free expression",<ref name=HRW>{{cite web |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/11/28/uae-prison-sentence-activists-attack-free-expression |title=UAE: Prison Sentence for Activists an Attack on Free Expression |author= |date=28 November 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> and [[Front Line (NGO)|Front Line Defenders]], the [[Index on Censorship]], and the [[Arabic Network for Human Rights Information]] also called for the men's release.<ref name=HRW /> Because of his academic background, bin Ghaith's trial was also protested by the Committee for Human Rights of the [[US National Academy of Sciences]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sites.nationalacademies.org/PGA/humanrights/PGA_066190 |title=Case Information |author= |date=1 December 2011 |work= |publisher=Committee for Human Rights of the US [[National Academy of Sciences]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> [[Scholars at Risk]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scholarsatrisk.nyu.edu/Events-News/Article-Detail.php?art_uid=2736 |title=DUBAI: Scholar's detention erodes UAE's reputation |author=Brendan O'Malley |date=24 April 2011 |work= |publisher=Scholars at Risk |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> and the [[Committee of Concerned Scientists]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://concernedscientists.org/2011/11/ccs-welcomes-release-of-professor-nasser-bin-ghaith-of-the-uae/ |title=CCS Welcomes Release of Professor Nasser Bin Ghaith of the UAE |author= |date=29 November 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Committee of Concerned Scientists]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref>
==Trial, conviction, and pardon== Their trial began on 14 June 2011 in [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref name=NYT /> A Human Rights Watch spokesman criticized the "public relations campaign" of the UAE government against the defendants, stating that dozens of pro-government demonstrators were attending the trial to protest the five prisoners.<ref name=NYT /> The government charged the prisoners with violating article 176 of the UAE Penal Code, which criminalizes insults to the nation's leadership;<ref name=AI1/> the prosecutor's case focused on their posts to an online pro-democracy forum, which had by then been shut down and replaced with a travel service.<ref name=O/> On 18 July, the UAE Five pleaded not guilty.<ref name=BBC2 /> Amnesty International later condemned their trial as "fundamentally unfair" and "marred with irregularities", stating that the defendants had been "denied any meaningful opportunity to challenge the charges and the evidence against them".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/actioncenter/actions/uaa11111.pdf |title='UAE Five' Risk Heavy Sentence for Insult |author= |date=11 November 2011 |work= |publisher=Amnesty International |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> Human Rights Watch also described the trial as "grossly unfair".<ref name=AJ />
On 3 October, the UAE Five refused to attend a session of their trial, demanding that the hearings be opened to the public and that they be allowed to question witnesses.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/10/2011102131053462460.html |title=UAE activists boycott 'unfair' trial |author= |date=3 October 2011 |work= |publisher=[[Al Jazeera]] |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> On 13 November, with the trial still in progress, the five began a [[hunger strike]] to protest their continued detention; Human Rights Watch reported that the five were in poor health.<ref name=HRW/> On 27 November, the panel of four judges sentenced bin Ghaith, Dalk, al-Khamis, and Khaleq to two years' imprisonment, and Mansoor to three years.<ref name=AJ>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111128135953601809.html |title=UAE pardons jailed activists |author= |date=28 November 2011 |work= |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> Following the announcement of the verdict, a pro-government protester reportedly assaulted a relative of one of the defendants despite the heavy security presence.<ref name=HRW/>
The following day, however, the five received a presidential pardon and were released.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-15922492 |title=Five jailed UAE activists 'receive presidential pardon' |author= |date=28 November 2011 |work= |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> The office of President Khalifa declined to comment to reporters on the reason for the pardon.<ref name=AJ /> Bin Ghaith told reporters that he was glad to be free, but that he felt that the trial had been "a sad moment for our homeland, a beginning of a [[police state]] that has tarnished the image of the UAE forever".<ref name=AJ />
==Subsequent arrests== ===Ahmed Mansoor Al Shehhi=== {{main|Ahmed Mansoor}} Ahmed Mansoor was arrested again on March 19, 2017, at his Ajman home, on charges of publishing false information, inciting hatred, and defaming the UAE online and "seeking to damage the relationship of the UAE with its neighbors". He was also accused of conspiring with a terrorist organization but was found innocent of that charge.<ref name="monde">http://www.lemonde.fr/proche-orient/article/2017/03/22/aux-emirats-arabes-unis-la-derniere-voix-libre-baillonnee_5099030_3218.html</ref> He was subsequently charged with 10 years in prison and 1,000,000 Emirati Dirham (approximately USD $270,000) fine.<ref name="National1">{{cite news|url=https://www.thenational.ae/uae/courts/emirati-convicted-for-second-time-of-insulting-country-and-leaders-1.735523|title=Emirati convicted for second time of insulting country and leaders |publisher=The National|date=May 30, 2018 }}</ref> Amnesty International criticized the United Arab Emirates for Mansoor's verdict and called the charge a "devastating blow to freedom of expression in the country" and called for the unconditional release of Mansoor.<ref name="amnestry">{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2018/05/uae-activist-ahmed-mansoor-sentenced-to-10-years-in-prison-for-social-media-posts/|title=UAE: Activist Ahmed Mansoor sentenced to 10 years in prison for social media posts|publisher= Amnesty International|date=31 May 2018}}</ref>
Mansoor received the [[Martin Ennals Award for Human Rights Defenders]] in 2015 prior to his imprisonment.<ref name="monde"/>
===Ahmed Abdul Khaleq=== {{main article|Ahmed Abdul Khaleq}} Ahmed Abdul Khaleq was again arrested by authorities for his alleged ties to [[Al Islah (United Arab Emirates)|al-Islah]] in May 2012, a political organization with roots in the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] and is listed as a terrorist organization in the UAE.<ref name=AI2>{{cite web |url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/uae-bidun-blogger-forced-leave-country-raising-alarm-after-wave-arbitrary-arrests-2012-07-16 |title=UAE: Bidun blogger forced to leave country, raising alarm after wave of arbitrary arrests |date=16 July 2012 |publisher=Amnesty International |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> Since Khaleq was not an Emirati citizen (previously a [[bedoon]] and holds a Comorian passport), he was presented with the option of being deported or conviction and imprisonment. Khaleq opted to leave for Thailand, departing for [[Bangkok]] on 16 July, 2012.<ref name=AI2/><ref name=R167>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-uae-rights-activistbre86f0vp-20120716,0,433526.story |title=UAE stateless rights activist says expelled to Thailand |author=Rania El Gamal |date=16 July 2012 |work=The Chicago Tribune |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref>
[[Human Rights Watch]] criticized the arrest, calling the action an "unlawful expulsion" motivated by the government's desire to stifle dissent.<ref name=R167>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-uae-rights-activistbre86f0vp-20120716,0,433526.story |title=UAE stateless rights activist says expelled to Thailand |author=Rania El Gamal |date=16 July 2012 |work=The Chicago Tribune |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref>
